title: Preparing for a difficult 1-on-1 with an underperformer
prompt:
I'm preparing for a 1-on-1 with a direct report who has been underperforming for the past {timeframe}. Specific issues: {issues}. I've already given informal feedback on {date}. Help me structure this conversation using the SBI (Situation-Behavior-Impact) framework. I need:
1. Opening that sets psychological safety
2. 2-3 specific SBI statements for the issues
3. Questions to understand their perspective and blockers
4. Concrete next steps with measurable outcomes and a timeline
5. How to document this conversation for HR if needed
context: Use before a 1-on-1 where you need to address performance issues directly but compassionately. Best used after you've already given informal feedback at least once.
output_format: Structured conversation plan with talking points, questions, and follow-up actions
example: I'm preparing for a 1-on-1 with a direct report who has been underperforming for the past 6 weeks. Specific issues: missed two sprint commitments, PRs have had recurring quality issues flagged in review, stopped attending team ceremonies without explanation. I've already given informal feedback on Jan 15. Help me structure this conversation...

title: 30-day check-in with a new hire
prompt:
I have a 30-day check-in with {name}, a new {role} who joined my team on {start_date}. Their onboarding buddy is {buddy}. So far I've observed: {observations}. Generate a 1-on-1 agenda that covers:
1. How they're feeling about the team and codebase
2. Whether onboarding has gaps (without leading them)
3. Early signals of their working style and communication preferences
4. Any friction with tooling, process, or team norms
5. What success looks like for their 60-day and 90-day milestones
context: Use at the 30-day mark for new hires. This is your best window to catch onboarding problems and set expectations before habits form.
output_format: 1-on-1 agenda with open-ended questions and follow-up prompts
example: I have a 30-day check-in with Sarah, a new Senior Backend Engineer who joined my team on Jan 5. Their onboarding buddy is Marcus. So far I've observed: she's shipping code but seems hesitant to push back in code reviews, and she eats lunch alone most days.

title: Skip-level 1-on-1 question bank
prompt:
I'm running skip-level 1-on-1s with my reports' direct reports this quarter. The team is {team_size} people across {num_managers} managers. I want to surface issues that my managers might not be escalating. Generate 10 skip-level questions that:
1. Don't undermine the direct manager's authority
2. Surface process and communication pain points
3. Gauge psychological safety on the team
4. Identify hidden talent and flight risks
5. Feel conversational, not like an interrogation
context: Use quarterly or when you suspect information isn't flowing up properly. Critical when you're new to a role managing managers.
output_format: Numbered list of questions with brief rationale for each
example: I'm running skip-level 1-on-1s with my reports' direct reports this quarter. The team is 24 people across 3 managers.

title: Re-onboarding someone returning from extended leave
prompt:
A team member is returning from {leave_type} leave after {duration}. While they were out: {changes}. Help me plan their first week back:
1. What to cover in our first 1-on-1 (without overwhelming them)
2. How to ramp them back into the codebase and current projects
3. What NOT to do (common manager mistakes when someone returns)
4. How to handle any shifted responsibilities or role changes sensitively
context: Use before someone returns from parental leave, medical leave, sabbatical, or any absence longer than 4 weeks.
output_format: First-week plan with day-by-day suggestions and 1-on-1 talking points
example: A team member is returning from parental leave after 4 months. While they were out: we migrated from monolith to microservices, hired 2 new engineers, and their tech lead left the company.

title: Team health assessment after a rough quarter
prompt:
My team just finished a rough quarter. Context: {context}. I want to assess team health without it feeling like another meeting. Design a lightweight async team health check that:
1. Covers the 5 dimensions: psychological safety, workload sustainability, clarity of purpose, trust in leadership, growth opportunities
2. Takes <5 minutes to complete
3. Surfaces real signal (not just polite answers)
4. Includes 2-3 follow-up actions I should take regardless of results
5. Suggests how to share results back transparently
context: Use after a rough quarter, reorg, layoffs, or when you sense morale is low but can't pinpoint why.
output_format: Survey template (5-7 questions) with scoring rubric and action plan template
example: My team just finished a rough quarter. Context: we shipped a major migration under pressure, lost our most senior engineer to burnout, and the product roadmap changed twice.

title: Mediating conflict between two engineers
prompt:
Two engineers on my team ({person_a} and {person_b}) have an ongoing conflict around {topic}. It's manifesting as: {symptoms}. Other team members are starting to notice. Help me:
1. Assess whether this is a technical disagreement, interpersonal friction, or values misalignment
2. Plan separate conversations with each person
3. Decide whether/when to bring them together
4. Set ground rules if I do mediate
5. Know when to escalate to HR vs. handle it myself
context: Use when conflict between team members is affecting team dynamics. Don't wait until it's a full crisis.
output_format: Decision tree + conversation scripts for each phase
example: Two engineers (Alex and Jordan) have an ongoing conflict around code review standards. It's manifesting as: passive-aggressive PR comments, Jordan going around Alex to get PRs approved by others, and awkward silences in standups.

title: Rebuilding trust after layoffs
prompt:
My company just had layoffs. My team lost {num_lost} of {team_size} people. The remaining team is {mood}. I need to:
1. Address the elephant in the room in our next team meeting — give me specific words, not platitudes
2. Redistribute work from departed members without burning out survivors
3. Rebuild psychological safety when people are updating their LinkedIn
4. Be honest about what I know and don't know about future cuts
5. Identify who's most at risk of leaving and how to have that conversation
context: Use within the first week after layoffs. Speed matters — silence from leadership gets filled with rumors.
output_format: Team meeting script + individual check-in framework + 30-day stabilization plan
example: My company just had layoffs. My team lost 3 of 10 people. The remaining team is shell-shocked and barely talking in Slack.

title: Diagnosing remote team disconnection
prompt:
My remote/hybrid team of {size} seems disconnected. Signals: {signals}. We're spread across {timezones} timezones. Audit our current async practices and suggest:
1. What rituals to add, modify, or kill
2. How to create organic social connection without forced fun
3. Communication norms that reduce isolation without adding meetings
4. How to spot someone struggling when you can't see body language
context: Use when remote team engagement drops or when onboarding remote team members who seem isolated.
output_format: Audit of current practices + specific ritual recommendations with time investment estimates
example: My remote team of 8 seems disconnected. Signals: cameras off in all meetings, Slack channels are quiet except for transactional messages, two people missed the optional team social three times in a row. We're spread across 3 timezones.

title: Blameless post-mortem facilitation guide
prompt:
We had a {severity} incident: {brief_description}. Duration: {duration}. Impact: {impact}. I need to facilitate a blameless post-mortem. Generate:
1. A pre-meeting async template for participants to fill out their timeline independently
2. Facilitation guide with specific questions that drive toward systemic causes (not individual blame)
3. How to redirect if someone starts finger-pointing
4. Action item framework (distinguish: fix the immediate thing, prevent the class of issue, improve detection)
5. Follow-up cadence to make sure action items actually get done
context: Use within 48 hours of incident resolution while details are fresh. Send the async template immediately, schedule the meeting for 2-3 days out.
output_format: Async pre-work template + facilitation script + action item tracker template
example: We had a P1 incident: payment processing was down for 4 hours on a Friday night because a config change in the feature flag service cascaded to the payments microservice. Duration: 4 hours. Impact: ~$200K in failed transactions, 3 engineers pulled from weekend.

title: Identifying incident patterns across multiple post-mortems
prompt:
Review these incident summaries from the past {timeframe}:
{incident_list}

Identify:
1. Systemic patterns (are we seeing the same class of failure?)
2. Which action items from previous retros actually got completed vs. ignored
3. Team/service ownership gaps that keep appearing
4. Whether our detection/alerting is improving or stagnating
5. A prioritized list of infrastructure/process investments that would prevent the top 3 patterns
6. How to present this to leadership to get budget/headcount
context: Use quarterly when reviewing incident trends. Turns individual incidents into a strategic reliability narrative for leadership.
output_format: Pattern analysis report with trend charts description, prioritized investment recommendations, and executive summary
example: Review these incident summaries from the past quarter: 1) DB connection pool exhaustion (3x), 2) Deployment rollback failures (2x), 3) Third-party API timeout cascades (4x), 4) Certificate expiry (1x)

title: Extracting and spreading learnings from an incident
prompt:
We completed a post-mortem for {incident}. Key findings: {findings}. The team that owns this service learned a lot, but other teams face similar risks. Help me:
1. Write a concise incident digest for the engineering-wide audience (technical but accessible)
2. Identify which other teams should review their systems for the same vulnerability
3. Create a 'lessons learned' that's actually useful (not just 'we should have had better monitoring')
4. Suggest a lightweight way to verify other teams actually acted on the learning
context: Use after post-mortem is complete to spread learnings across the org. Most orgs do post-mortems but fail at cross-pollination.
output_format: Engineering digest post + targeted team action items + verification checklist
example: We completed a post-mortem for the payment processing outage. Key findings: feature flag changes weren't tested against downstream services, no circuit breaker on the payments→flag-service dependency, on-call runbook was outdated.

title: Tech debt prioritization framework
prompt:
My team has accumulated significant tech debt. Here's what we're dealing with:
{debt_items}

Our business context: {business_context}. Team capacity: {capacity}.

Help me:
1. Score each item on: blast radius (how many teams/features does it affect), velocity drag (how much does it slow us down weekly), risk (what breaks if we don't fix it), and effort
2. Create a prioritized roadmap that interleaves debt paydown with feature work
3. Frame this for my product counterpart who thinks all tech debt work is gold-plating
4. Suggest a sustainable 'tech debt budget' (% of capacity) with guardrails
5. Define 'done' for each item so we don't gold-plate it ourselves
context: Use when planning a quarter and negotiating tech debt capacity with product. Having a framework prevents the annual 'we need to stop and rewrite everything' conversation.
output_format: Scored matrix + quarterly roadmap + product stakeholder talking points
example: My team's tech debt: 1) Monolithic test suite takes 45min (blocks CI), 2) Legacy auth service on deprecated framework, 3) No DB migration tooling (manual SQL), 4) Flaky integration tests (2-3 reruns per PR), 5) Logging inconsistency across services. Business context: launching in new market Q2. Team: 6 engineers.

title: Build vs. buy decision framework
prompt:
We need to decide whether to build or buy for: {capability}. Context: {context}. Evaluate this decision across:
1. Total cost of ownership over 3 years (not just license vs. eng time)
2. Strategic differentiation (is this core to our business or commodity?)
3. Integration complexity and vendor lock-in risk
4. Team capability and maintenance burden
5. Time to value (we need this by {deadline})
6. What we'd lose by NOT building it ourselves (institutional knowledge, customization)
Give me a recommendation with your confidence level and the key assumption that would flip your answer.
context: Use when evaluating vendors, considering building internal tools, or during architecture reviews. Forces structured thinking instead of engineer-default 'let's build it'.
output_format: Decision matrix + recommendation with confidence level + assumption sensitivity analysis
example: We need to decide whether to build or buy for: internal feature flag service. Context: we currently use LaunchDarkly ($40K/year), 12 engineers use it daily, we need custom targeting rules for our ML pipeline that LD doesn't support well. Deadline: Q2.

title: Architecture decision record (ADR) review
context: Use during architecture reviews or when a tech lead proposes a significant system change. Best used as async review before the meeting.
output_format: Structured review with challenge questions, risk assessment, and go/no-go recommendation
example: Title: Migrate from PostgreSQL to DynamoDB for the user activity service. Context: we're hitting write throughput limits at peak, ~50K writes/sec. Proposed: move to DynamoDB with single-table design. Alternatives: PostgreSQL with read replicas and write partitioning, or Aurora Serverless.

title: Platform team pitch to leadership
prompt:
I want to propose creating a platform team (or investing more in platform work). Current state: {current_state}. Pain points: {pain_points}. I need:
1. A business case that translates developer experience into business metrics
2. ROI calculation framework (developer hours saved × loaded cost vs. platform team cost)
3. Phased rollout plan (what to build first for maximum credibility)
4. Success metrics that leadership will care about
5. How to avoid the 'platform team that nobody uses' antipattern
6. Counter-arguments to 'just let teams build their own tooling'
context: Use when you've identified repeated toil across teams that a platform team could address. The pitch must speak business language, not engineer language.
output_format: Executive pitch deck outline + ROI model + phased roadmap + success metrics
example: Current state: 8 product teams, each maintaining their own CI/CD pipelines, deployment scripts, and observability setup. Pain points: teams spend ~20% of capacity on undifferentiated operational work, new services take 3 weeks to get to production, no consistent SLO framework.

title: Structured interview rubric design
prompt:
I'm designing a structured interview loop for a {level} {role}. Team context: {team_context}. The biggest gaps on my team right now are: {gaps}.

Design an interview loop with:
1. 4-5 interview rounds with specific focus areas (not generic 'culture fit')
2. Calibrated rubric for each round (what does a 1-4 score look like specifically?)
3. Questions that reveal signal, not rehearsed answers
4. How to assess for the specific gaps without making it obvious
5. Debrief structure that minimizes groupthink and anchoring bias
6. Red flags and green flags specific to this role/level
context: Use when opening a new role or when your current interview process has a high false-positive rate. Better signal = fewer mis-hires.
output_format: Interview loop design + per-round rubric + scorecard template + debrief facilitation guide
example: I'm designing a structured interview loop for a Senior Backend Engineer. Team context: distributed payments team, high-stakes system, on-call rotation. Biggest gaps: someone who can own system design end-to-end and mentor mid-level engineers.

title: Hiring pipeline analysis and optimization
prompt:
Here's our hiring pipeline data for {role} over the past {timeframe}:
{pipeline_data}

Analyze:
1. Where are we losing good candidates? (conversion rates at each stage)
2. Is our time-to-hire competitive? (benchmark against market)
3. Are we over/under-indexing on any interview signal?
4. Diversity and inclusion audit — where does our pipeline narrow?
5. Specific changes to improve our offer-accept rate
6. Should we adjust level, comp, or job description based on who's applying vs. who we want?
context: Use when a role has been open for >6 weeks or when you're not getting quality candidates. Data-driven hiring beats gut feel.
output_format: Funnel analysis with conversion rates + benchmarks + specific recommendations ranked by impact
example: Pipeline for Senior Backend Engineer over past 3 months: 200 applicants → 40 phone screens → 20 technical screens → 8 onsites → 3 offers → 1 accept. Time-to-hire: 47 days average.

title: Closing a strong candidate who's comparing offers
prompt:
We want to extend an offer to {candidate_name} for {role}. They're also talking to {competitors}. Our strengths: {strengths}. Our weaknesses vs competitors: {weaknesses}. Their priorities seem to be: {priorities}.

Help me:
1. Craft a compelling offer narrative (not just comp numbers)
2. Identify which of their priorities we can uniquely address
3. Prepare for their likely objections
4. Design the 'sell call' agenda (who should be on it besides me?)
5. What to do if they want to negotiate beyond our band
context: Use after a strong onsite when you know the candidate has competing offers. The sell phase is where many engineering orgs lose top talent.
output_format: Sell strategy + call agenda + objection handling matrix + negotiation boundaries
example: We want to extend an offer to a Senior SRE. They're also talking to Stripe and Datadog. Our strengths: interesting scale problems, strong team, remote-friendly. Weaknesses: lower base comp, less brand recognition. Their priorities: technical growth and work-life balance.

title: Building a promotion case
prompt:
I want to build a promotion case for {name} from {current_level} to {target_level}. They've been at current level for {duration}. Key accomplishments: {accomplishments}. Areas where they already operate at next level: {strengths}. Gaps: {gaps}.

Help me:
1. Structure the promotion packet using {company_framework_or_generic}
2. Map their work to next-level expectations with specific evidence
3. Identify 2-3 'stretch assignments' to close remaining gaps before the review cycle
4. Draft peer feedback request that guides reviewers to provide useful signal
5. Anticipate calibration committee pushback and prepare counter-arguments
6. Create a timeline to submit by {review_date}
context: Use 2-3 months before a promotion cycle. A strong written case is the #1 factor in successful promotions — not the work itself.
output_format: Promotion packet draft + gap-closing plan + peer feedback template + calibration prep notes
example: Building a promotion case for Maya from Senior to Staff Engineer. She's been Senior for 2.5 years. Key accomplishments: led the API platform migration, mentors 3 engineers, wrote the team's RFC process. Already operating at Staff: cross-team technical influence, architecture reviews. Gaps: hasn't driven a company-wide initiative yet.

title: Delivering difficult but growth-oriented feedback
prompt:
I need to give {name} feedback about {topic}. Specific examples: {examples}. This is {severity: minor/significant/critical}. Our relationship context: {relationship}.

Help me:
1. Frame this as growth feedback, not criticism
2. Use concrete examples (not 'you always...')
3. Connect the behavior to its impact on the team/their career
4. Propose a specific development plan (not just 'do better')
5. Script the opening — first 2 sentences matter most
6. Plan for the three possible reactions: accepts it, gets defensive, shuts down
context: Use when you've observed a pattern that needs addressing. Don't wait for performance review season — timely feedback is kind feedback.
output_format: Feedback script with contingency branches + development plan + follow-up schedule
example: I need to give feedback to Tom about his communication in cross-team meetings. Examples: interrupted the PM twice in last planning, sent a combative Slack message to the design team about scope, and escalated to my boss without talking to me first. Severity: significant. We have a good relationship — he'll probably be receptive but embarrassed.

title: Creating a growth framework for your team
prompt:
I need to create (or adapt) a growth/leveling framework for my {team_type} team. Current team composition: {composition}. Our company {has/doesn't have} a formal engineering ladder.

Help me build a practical framework that:
1. Defines clear expectations at each level for: technical skill, scope of impact, leadership/influence, and delivery
2. Includes observable behaviors (not vague statements like 'demonstrates expertise')
3. Distinguishes IC and management tracks clearly
4. Gives engineers a self-assessment tool
5. Helps me have consistent career conversations across the team
6. Fits on 2 pages (not a 50-page document nobody reads)
context: Use when joining a new team without a clear ladder, or when your existing framework generates more confusion than clarity.
output_format: 2-page leveling matrix + self-assessment template + manager calibration guide
example: I need a growth framework for my backend platform team. Composition: 2 mid-level, 3 senior, 1 staff. Company doesn't have a formal engineering ladder beyond 'junior/mid/senior'.

title: Retaining a flight risk
prompt:
I think {name} ({role}, {tenure}) might be a flight risk. Signals: {signals}. They're critical to the team because: {why_critical}. Current comp: {comp_context}.

Help me:
1. Validate whether these signals actually indicate flight risk or something else
2. Plan a conversation that doesn't tip my hand ('I know you're interviewing')
3. Identify what levers I have: comp, role change, new challenges, flexibility, visibility
4. Decide what I'm willing to offer proactively vs. reactively (counter-offer is usually too late)
5. If they do leave — transition plan to minimize blast radius
context: Use when you notice disengagement signals in a key team member. Acting early gives you options; acting after they have an offer gives you none.
output_format: Flight risk assessment + retention conversation plan + contingency plan if they leave
example: I think Sarah (Staff Engineer, 3 years) might be a flight risk. Signals: declined to lead the Q2 initiative she'd normally jump at, updated LinkedIn, asked about our equity vesting schedule. Critical because: she's the only person who deeply understands our data pipeline. Comp: at band midpoint, no refresh grant in 18 months.

title: Writing an executive status update
prompt:
I need to write a {cadence} executive update for {audience}. My team's recent work: {work_summary}. Key wins: {wins}. Risks/blockers: {risks}. Upcoming: {upcoming}.

Write this update following these principles:
1. Lead with business impact, not technical details
2. RAG status (Red/Amber/Green) for each workstream with crisp one-liner justification
3. Risks framed as 'X will happen if we don't Y' (not passive 'there are some concerns')
4. Asks are specific and actionable ('I need a decision on X by Friday' not 'we could use some support')
5. Keep it under 300 words — executives scan, they don't read
6. Include one thing that makes the team's work visible (demo link, metric, quote)
context: Use weekly or bi-weekly for VP/C-level updates. The exec update is your team's marketing — it determines resourcing, attention, and air cover.
output_format: Formatted executive update (300 words max) with RAG status, metrics, risks, and asks
example: Weekly update for VP of Engineering. Team work: migrating checkout to new payment processor. Wins: successfully migrated 30% of traffic with 0 errors. Risks: third-party API rate limits may block full migration by deadline. Upcoming: load testing at 100% traffic next week.

title: Saying no to a stakeholder request
prompt:
A stakeholder ({name}, {role}) is requesting: {request}. Why I want to say no: {reasons}. Political context: {politics}. My relationship with them: {relationship}.

Help me:
1. Validate — am I right to push back, or am I being too protective of my team?
2. Craft a response that says no without using the word 'no'
3. Offer alternatives that address their underlying need (not their stated solution)
4. Quantify the trade-off: 'If we do X, we can't do Y — which matters more?'
5. Escalation strategy if they push — when to hold firm vs. compromise
6. Written follow-up to create a paper trail
context: Use when you get an urgent request that would derail your team's commitments. The skill of saying no is the most important and least taught management skill.
output_format: Response script (verbal + written) + trade-off analysis + escalation playbook
example: VP of Sales is requesting: 'We need a custom dashboard for our top enterprise client by end of month.' Why I want to say no: it would pull 2 engineers off the reliability work we committed to after last month's outage. Politics: Sales VP has the CEO's ear, my VP told me to 'figure it out'. Relationship: we've clashed before on scope.

title: Cross-functional alignment when priorities clash
prompt:
I need to align with {teams_involved} on {initiative}. The conflict: {conflict}. Each team's perspective:
{team_perspectives}

Help me:
1. Find the shared objective that all teams actually agree on
2. Identify where the real disagreement is (often it's about sequencing, not goals)
3. Propose a concrete plan that gives each team enough of what they need
4. Design the meeting agenda for the alignment session
5. Define clear ownership and decision rights (RACI or similar, but actually useful)
6. Draft a written agreement we can reference when alignment drifts
context: Use when cross-team work is stuck due to conflicting priorities. Most alignment problems are really communication problems — everyone optimizes for their own local metrics.
output_format: Alignment proposal + meeting agenda + RACI matrix + written agreement template
example: Need to align Engineering, Product, and Data Science on the ML personalization initiative. Conflict: Product wants to ship a V1 fast with simple rules, Data Science wants to build a proper ML pipeline first, and my engineering team is worried about operational complexity. Each team reports to a different VP.

title: Communicating an org change to your team
prompt:
I need to communicate the following org change to my team: {change}. Reason: {reason}. What I can share: {shareable}. What I can't share: {confidential}. Timeline: {timeline}. People most affected: {affected}.

Help me:
1. Script the team announcement (honest but not panic-inducing)
2. Plan individual conversations with most-affected people BEFORE the team announcement
3. Prepare for the questions I'll definitely get (and the ones I can't answer yet)
4. Create an FAQ doc to reduce hallway anxiety
5. Define the transition plan with clear dates and owners
6. Follow-up communication cadence for the next 30 days
context: Use before any reorg, team split/merge, manager change, or reporting structure change. People handle change better when they hear it from their direct manager with context, not via an all-hands Slack message.
output_format: Announcement script + individual conversation plans + FAQ + transition timeline + 30-day comms plan
example: My team of 10 is being split into two teams of 5. I'll manage one, and we're hiring a new manager for the other. Reason: we've grown beyond effective single-team size. Can't share: who the new manager hire is (still interviewing). Most affected: the 5 people moving to the new team, especially the senior engineer who expected to be promoted to manage it.
